709429f-a.text:
Second Ave., north from East 34th Street. Intersection in the foreground is East 35th Street. On the right, north of that point appears a row of buildings that were included in the demolition for St. Gabriels
Park.
About 1891.

707823f-a.text:
3iAI. At 32nd Ave 34th St, APRIL 1902
Showing the Second Avenue Elevated Railroad (Metropolitan E1evated Railway Company), and the joint station of the Second Avenue "V' E the 34th Street Spur (Third Avenue Line) at Second Avenue E 34th Street. Looking north. The sub structures were taken possession of by the City of New York, July 15, 1930,
and removed.

707830f-a.text:
Second Avenue, north from East 35th Street
as viewed from the extremity of the Downtown Station
at 34th Street of the Second Avenue "El".
To the right is St. Gabriel's Park, the white building housing the New York Public Library branch of that name, the Hall structure, and the Church proper on 37th Street. All of these will be gone in early 1940 as this entire block will be cleared for the plaza approach to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. Note in the background the group of apartment buildings forming Tudor City. Close observation will distinguish the fact of almost completion of same. Subsequently other units will be erected and the skyline changed, thereby obliterating a view of the long roofed Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled Children. This appears in the due center of this photo.
February 5, 1928
P. L. Sperr

730239f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - 34th Street (East) - 2nd Avenue (Northwest).]
730239f-a.text:
A general view northwestward from the "El" platform at E. 54th Street and Second Avenue, towards the Midtown-42nd Street district. Note the absence of the tall structures that will rise in the ensuing year. Close to the right margin is the Commodore Hotel with the Graybar Building above same. Both are on Lexington Avenue, north of 42nd Street. A later view will find these
obstructed by the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings.
February 5, 1928.
.L. Sperr

712110f-a.text:
East 34th Street, West from Second Avenue (foreground, not seen) showing the spur that connects the Second and Third elevated lines at this point. The photographer is viewing westward from atop No. 321 East 34th Street, a building between First and Second Avenues. Note
the absence of the Empire State Bldg.
September 16, 1929.
P. L. Sperr

712116f-a.text:
34th Street, north side, west from No. 305 East, east of Second Avenue, showing the double Elevated station at the junction of the regular Second Avenue line and the 34th Street spur; the
latter is shortly to go out of use.
March 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

712109f-a.text:
34th Street, west from and including Second Avenue. This shows the elevated structure running from Third Avenue to the East River. At the time this branch was built the law stated that all elevated lines must connect with railroads or ferries. It was on this branch that electricity was first used for experimentation, preparatory to electrifying all the lines. The structure is about
to be torn down.
The picture shows a fine view of the Empire State Building.
June 25, 1931.
International News.

712111f-a.text:
3dth Street, north side, west from and including Second Ave. showing the double Elevated station st Second Avenue and 3 Street. Service has been discontinued on the 34th Street and the elevated structure taken down east of Second Avenue
September 11, 1931.
L. Sperr.

712118f-a.text:
243 East 34th Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Second Ave. Shown is the Greek Orthodox Church of St. John the Baptist, Rr:  2, . CS
Ce.0
October 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

712122f-a.text:
222 to 246 East 34th Street, south side, east from a point midway between Third and Second Aves., and to the latter, showing in the foreground four 4-story tenements (Nos. 222 to 228 inclusive) that will be demolished and upon whose site will rise a 9-story modern,part glass, apartment house. For an account of same, see, the New York Times of
January 23, 1938.
January 30, 1938.
George D. Chinn.

712125f-a.text:
East 34th Street, north side, west from Second to Third Avenues. No. 221-29 is U. S. Post Office Station "F" and was the former Borden Co. plant site. To the right is the generating plant of the Manhattan Railroad Co. (Station No. 6) that hooked
up to the spur line on this thoroughfare.
October 16, 1938
George D. Chinn

January 8, 1939

707827f-a.text:
Second Avenue, east side, south from E. 35th to 34th Streets, showing a row of old tenements occupying this frontage. Note the 34th Street "El" station at the right and its high double platform.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707828f-a.text:
Second Avenue, east side, north from E. 34th to 35th Streets . North of the latter point,(at the left) appears St. Gabriel's Park and the Public Library of the sme name.
January 8, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707837f-a.text:
Second Avenue, west side, south from E. 36th Street. Note the "El" station at 34th Street.
January 6, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York Gity Tunnel Authority

707838f-a.text:
Second Avenue, east side, south from E. 36th Street, showing the westerly half of St. Gabriel's Park. Across same and facing the park is Columbia University's Institute of Public Administration. This building formerly housed said institutions College of Dental and Oral Surgery. The large loft structure is the Harriet
Hubbard Ayer building No. 317-323 E. 34th Street.
January 6, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712093f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, south side, east from Second Avenue to
the East River.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712094f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, north side, east from Second Avenue to the East River. Overhead is the Second Avenue'El" and its 34th Street Station. Note at the right the T beams to which were hooked the 34th Street spur line that formerly ran to the Borden Avenue Ferry terminal at the waters edge. To the center of this view and slightly east of the corner is the 4 story building housing Columbia University's College of Dental and Oral Surgery. Adjoining same is the 12 story Harriet Hubbard Ayer Building (No. 317-323 E. 34th Street.)
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712096f-b.text:
East 34th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of Second Avenue (extreme right, not shown), as photographed in a northeastward direction. On the left margin appears a portion of the new Post Office Station F. Views 2 &: 3 detail the 3 story stable at No. 235 and the
adjacent generating plant at No 237.
May 26, 1939
No's. 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr

712096f-c.text:
East 34th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of Second Avenue (extreme right, not shown), as photographed in a northeastward direction. On the left margin appears a portion of the new Post Office Station F. Views 2 &: 3 detail the 3 story stable at No. 235 and the
adjacent generating plant at No 237.

No's. 1-2-3

712096f-a.text:

712108f-a.text:
East 34th Street, at Second Avenue, as photographed from the Harriet Hubbard Ayer Bldg., showing prominently the Second Avenue "El" station. The buildings included are on the south side of 34th Street, being east and west of the Avenue. The photographer is viewing southwestward.
October 13, 1939
P. L. Sperr

712114f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, north side, west of Second Avenue, showing prominently the block extending between Second and Third Avenues. In the center of sime is a 3 story structure housing U. S. Post Cffice Station "F". This site is proposed as the future entrance to the Midtown Queens Tunnel under the East River. It has only been possible in the last year to take such a photo since the spur line connecting the two "El' lines was demolished (Surmmer 1938). The link that extended to the East River came down in 1930.
January 7, 1939
Son.ach Photo Service
Ne~ York Wity Tunnel Authority
LINE AUTROR ITY  IT

712126f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, south sce, west from Second to Third
AVenues, showing a row of structures that will remain and face the entrance to the 38th Street tunnel under the East Tiver. On the two Avenues nentioned appear tneir respective "El" lines and 34th Street stations. Srevious to the Summer of 1938 these were joined by a spur line, a remnant ef a link with the Ferry to Borcen Avenue. Early legislatien neccessitated same, stating that all transportation facilities join up with either railroad terminals or water facilities. The writer believes the drug store appearing on the left to be place of business from which Col. C'Brien emanated and was fatally attacked during the Draft Riots of 18o3. For accounts of same, see "Gangs cf New York" by H. Asbury and "Boss
Tweed" by Dennis Lynch etc.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712098f-b.text:
East 34th Street, north side, east of Second Avenue, showing the by-pass roadway leading to the Midtown Queens Tunnel under construction. This will run thru the 34th -35th Street block and into St. Gabriels Park. View 1 shows the Columbia University building at 310 being demolished. View 2 is the same site later showing the swath necessary. Note the library building on 36th Street still standing. View 3 is limited to the road
bed thru the Park.
1: October 11, 1939
2S3: April 11, 19440
P. L. Sperr

712106f-b.text:
East 34th Street, west from Second Avenue, showing this crosstown thoroughfare before end after the removal of the remaining portion of the spur line between the Second and Third Avenue's "E1" lines. This section was allowed to remain in a stripped condition because of the power supply house at the right margin. In the left background appear the blending 71st Regiment Armory tower and the Vanderbilt Hotel, overshadowed by the dominant Empire State Bldg.
1: April 26, 1937
23: May 27, 1939
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project
P. L. Sperr
